column2: It is moral cowardice to leave undone what one perceives to be right to do.

column2: Alluding to the head of the Ki family, [4] and the eight lines of posturers [5] before their ancestral hall, Confucius remarked, "If the Ki can allow himself to go to this extent, to what extent will he not allow himself to go?"
column3: Alluding to the head of the Ki family, [four] and the eight lines of posturers [five] before their ancestral hall, Confucius remarked, "If the Ki can allow himself to go to this extent, to what extent will he not allow himself to go?"

column2: The Three Families [6] were in the habit, during the Removal of the sacred vessels after sacrifice, of using the hymn commencing,
column3: The Three Families [six] were in the habit, during the Removal of the sacred vessels after sacrifice, of using the hymn commencing,

column2: Harmoniously the Princes Draw near with reverent tread, Assisting in his worship Heaven's Son, the great and dread.
column3: Harmoniously the Princes Draw near with reverent tread, Assisting in his worship Heaven's Son, the great and dread.

column2: How, exclaimed the Master, "can such words be appropriated in the ancestral hall of the Three Families?"
column3: How, exclaimed the Master, "can such words be appropriated in the ancestral hall of the Three Families?"

column2: Where a man, said he again, "has not the proper feelings due from one man to another, how will he stand as regards the Rules of Propriety?
column3: Where a man, said he again, "has not the proper feelings due from one man to another, how will he stand as regards the Rules of Propriety?

column2: And in such a case, what shall we say of his sense of harmony?"
column3: And in such a case, what shall we say of his sense of harmony?"

column2: On a question being put to him by Lin Fang, a disciple, as to what was the radical idea upon which the Rules of Propriety were based, the Master exclaimed, "Ah! that is a large question.
column3: On a question being put to him by Lin Fang, a disciple, as to what was the radical idea upon which the Rules of Propriety were based, the Master exclaimed, "Ah! that is a large question.

column2: As to some rules, where there is likelihood of extravagance, they would rather demand economy; in those which relate to mourning, and where there is likelihood of being easily satisfied, what is wanted is real sorrow."
column3: As to some rules, where there is likelihood of extravagance, they would rather demand economy; in those which relate to mourning, and where there is likelihood of being easily satisfied, what is wanted is real sorrow."

column2: Speaking of the disorder of the times he remarked that while the barbarians on the North and East had their Chieftains, we here in this great country had nothing to compare with them in that respect:--we had lost these distinctions!
column3: Speaking of the disorder of the times he remarked that while the barbarians on the North and East had their Chieftains, we here in this great country had nothing to compare with them in that respect:--we had lost these distinctions!

column2: Alluding to the matter of the Chief of the Ki family worshipping on Tai-shan, [7] the Master said to Yen Yu, "Cannot you save him from this?" He replied, "It is beyond my power." "Alas, alas!" exclaimed the Master, "are we to say that the spirits of T'ai-shan have not as much discernment as Lin Fang?"
column3: Alluding to the matter of the Chief of the Ki family worshipping on Tai shan, [seven] the Master said to Yen Yu, "Cannot you save him from this?" He replied, "It is beyond my power." "Alas, alas!" exclaimed the Master, "are we to say that the spirits of T'ai shan have not as much discernment as Lin Fang?"

column2: Of "the superior man," the Master observed, "In him there is no contentiousness.
column3: Of "the superior man," the Master observed, "In him there is no contentiousness.

column2: Say even that he does certainly contend with others, as in archery competitions; yet mark, in that case, how courteously he will bow and go up for the forfeit-cup, and come down again and give it to his competitor.
column3: Say even that he does certainly contend with others, as in archery competitions; yet mark, in that case, how courteously he will bow and go up for the forfeit cup, and come down again and give it to his competitor.

column2: In his very contest he is still the superior man."
column3: In his very contest he is still the superior man."

column2: Tsz-hia once inquired what inference might be drawn from the lines--

column2: Dimples playing in witching smile, Beautiful eyes, so dark, so bright! Oh, and her face may be thought the while Colored by art, red rose on white!
column3: Dimples playing in witching smile, Beautiful eyes, so dark, so bright! Oh, and her face may be thought the while Colored by art, red rose on white!

column2: Coloring, replied the Master, "requires a pure and clear background." "Then," said the other, "rules of ceremony require to have a background!" "Ah!" exclaimed the Master, "you are the man to catch the drift of my thought.
column3: Coloring, replied the Master, "requires a pure and clear background." "Then," said the other, "rules of ceremony require to have a background!" "Ah!" exclaimed the Master, "you are the man to catch the drift of my thought.

column2: Such as you may well introduce a discussion on the Odes."
column3: Such as you may well introduce a discussion on the Odes."

column2: Said the Master, "As regards the ceremonial adopted and enforced by the Hia dynasty, I am able to describe it, although their own descendants in the State of Ki can adduce no adequate testimony in favor of its use there.
column3: Said the Master, "As regards the ceremonial adopted and enforced by the Hia dynasty, I am able to describe it, although their own descendants in the State of Ki can adduce no adequate testimony in favor of its use there.

column2: So, too, I am able to describe the ceremonial of the Yin dynasty, although no more can the Sung people show sufficient reason for its continuance amongst themselves.
column3: So, too, I am able to describe the ceremonial of the Yin dynasty, although no more can the Sung people show sufficient reason for its continuance amongst themselves.

column2: And why cannot they do so?
column3: And why cannot they do so?

column2: Because they have not documents enough, nor men learned enough.
column3: Because they have not documents enough, nor men learned enough.

column2: If only they had such, I could refer them to them in support of their usages.
column3: If only they had such, I could refer them to them in support of their usages.

column2: When I am present at the great quinquennial sacrifice to the _manes_ of the royal ancestors, the Master said, "from the pouring-out of the oblation onwards, I have no heart to look on."
column3: When I am present at the great quinquennial sacrifice to the underscore manes underscore of the royal ancestors, the Master said, "from the pouring out of the oblation onwards, I have no heart to look on."

column2: Some one asked what was the purport of this great sacrifice, and the Master replied, "I cannot tell.
column3: Some one asked what was the purport of this great sacrifice, and the Master replied, "I cannot tell.

column2: The position in the empire of him who could tell you is as evident as when you look at this"--pointing to the palm of his hand.
column3: The position in the empire of him who could tell you is as evident as when you look at this"--pointing to the palm of his hand.

column2: When he offered sacrifices to his ancestors, he used to act as if they were present before him.
column3: When he offered sacrifices to his ancestors, he used to act as if they were present before him.

column2: In offering to other spirits it was the same.
column3: In offering to other spirits it was the same.

column2: He would say, "If I do not myself take part in my offerings, it is all the same as if I did not offer them."
column3: He would say, "If I do not myself take part in my offerings, it is all the same as if I did not offer them."

column2: Wang-sun Kia asked him once, "What says the proverb, 'Better to court favor in the kitchen than in the drawing-room'?"
column3: Wang sun Kia asked him once, "What says the proverb, 'Better to court favor in the kitchen than in the drawing room'?"

column2: The Master replied, "Nay, better say, He who has sinned against Heaven has none other to whom prayer may be addressed."
column3: The Master replied, "Nay, better say, He who has sinned against Heaven has none other to whom prayer may be addressed."

column2: Of the Chow dynasty the Master remarked, "It looks back upon two other dynasties; and what a rich possession it has in its records of those times!
column3: Of the Chow dynasty the Master remarked, "It looks back upon two other dynasties; and what a rich possession it has in its records of those times!

column2: I follow Chow!"
column3: I follow Chow!"

column2: On his first entry into the grand temple, he inquired about every matter connected with its usages.
column3: On his first entry into the grand temple, he inquired about every matter connected with its usages.

column2: Some one thereupon remarked, "Who says that the son of the man of Tsou [8] understands about ceremonial?
column3: Some one thereupon remarked, "Who says that the son of the man of Tsou [eight] understands about ceremonial?

column2: On entering the grand temple he inquired about everything."
column3: On entering the grand temple he inquired about everything."

column2: This remark coming to the Master's ears, he said, "What I did is part of the ceremonial!"
column3: This remark coming to the Master's ears, he said, "What I did is part of the ceremonial!"

column2: In archery, he said, "the great point to be observed is not simply the perforation of the leather; for men have not all the same strength.
column3: In archery, he said, "the great point to be observed is not simply the perforation of the leather; for men have not all the same strength.

column2: That was the fashion in the olden days."
column3: That was the fashion in the olden days."

column2: Once, seeing that his disciple Tsz-kung was desirous that the ceremonial observance of offering a sheep at the new moon might be dispensed with, the Master said, "Ah! you grudge the loss of the sheep; I grudge the loss of the ceremony."
column3: Once, seeing that his disciple t s z kung was desirous that the ceremonial observance of offering a sheep at the new moon might be dispensed with, the Master said, "Ah! you grudge the loss of the sheep; I grudge the loss of the ceremony."

column2: To serve one's ruler nowadays, he remarked, "fully complying with the Rules of Propriety, is regarded by others as toadyism!"
column3: To serve one's ruler nowadays, he remarked, "fully complying with the Rules of Propriety, is regarded by others as toadyism!"

column2: When Duke Ting questioned him as to how a prince should deal with his ministers, and how they in turn should serve their prince, Confucius said in reply, "In dealing with his ministers a prince should observe the proprieties; in serving his prince a minister should observe the duty of loyalty."
column3: When Duke Ting questioned him as to how a prince should deal with his ministers, and how they in turn should serve their prince, Confucius said in reply, "In dealing with his ministers a prince should observe the proprieties; in serving his prince a minister should observe the duty of loyalty."

column2: Referring to the First of the Odes, he remarked that it was mirthful without being lewd, and sad also without being painful.
column3: Referring to the First of the Odes, he remarked that it was mirthful without being lewd, and sad also without being painful.

column2: Duke Ngai asked the disciple Tsai Wo respecting the places for sacrificing to the Earth.
column3: Duke Ngai asked the disciple Tsai Wo respecting the places for sacrificing to the Earth.

column2: The latter replied, "The Family of the Great Yu, of the Hia dynasty, chose a place of pine trees; the Yin founders chose cypresses; and the Chow founders chestnut trees, solemn and majestic, to inspire, 'tis said, the people with feelings of awe."
column3: The latter replied, "The Family of the Great Yu, of the Hia dynasty, chose a place of pine trees; the Yin founders chose cypresses; and the Chow founders chestnut trees, solemn and majestic, to inspire, 'tis said, the people with feelings of awe."

column2: The Master on hearing of this exclaimed, "Never an allusion to things that have been enacted in the past!
column3: The Master on hearing of this exclaimed, "Never an allusion to things that have been enacted in the past!

column2: Never a remonstrance against what is now going on!
column3: Never a remonstrance against what is now going on!

column2: He has gone away without a word of censure."
column3: He has gone away without a word of censure."

column2: The Master once said of Kwan Chung, [9] "A small-minded man indeed!"
column3: The Master once said of Kwan Chung, [nine] "A small minded man indeed!"

column2: Was he miserly? some one asked.
column3: Was he miserly? some one asked.

column2: Miserly, indeed! said he; "not that: he married three rimes, and he was not a man who restricted his official business to too few hands--how could he be miserly?"
column3: Miserly, indeed! said he; "not that: he married three rimes, and he was not a man who restricted his official business to too few hands-how could he be miserly?"

column2: He knew the Rules of Propriety, I suppose?
column3: He knew the Rules of Propriety, I suppose?

column2: Judge:--Seeing that the feudal lords planted a screen at their gates, he too would have one at his!	Judge:--Seeing that the feudal lords planted a screen at their gates, he too would have one at his!
column3: true

column2: Seeing that when any two of the feudal lords met in friendly conclave they had an earthenware stand on which to place their inverted cups after drinking, he must have the same!
column3: Seeing that when any two of the feudal lords met in friendly conclave they had an earthenware stand on which to place their inverted cups after drinking, he must have the same!

column2: If he knew the Rules of Propriety, who is there that does not know them?"
column3: If he knew the Rules of Propriety, who is there that does not know them?"

column2: In a discourse to the Chief Preceptor of Music at the court of Lu, the Master said, "Music is an intelligible thing.
column3: In a discourse to the Chief Preceptor of Music at the court of Lu, the Master said, "Music is an intelligible thing.

column2: When you begin a performance, let all the various instruments produce as it were one sound (inharmonious); then, as you go on, bring out the harmony fully, distinctly, and with uninterrupted flow, unto the end."
column3: When you begin a performance, let all the various instruments produce as it were one sound (inharmonious); then, as you go on, bring out the harmony fully, distinctly, and with uninterrupted flow, unto the end."

column2: The warden of the border-town of I requested an interview with Confucius, and said, "When great men have come here, I have never yet failed to obtain a sight of them." The followers introduced him; and, on leaving, he said to them, "Sirs, why grieve at his loss of office?
column3: The warden of the border town of I requested an interview with Confucius, and said, "When great men have come here, I have never yet failed to obtain a sight of them." The followers introduced him; and, on leaving, he said to them, "Sirs, why grieve at his loss of office?

column2: The empire has for long been without good government; and Heaven is about to use your master as its edict-announcer."
column3: The empire has for long been without good government; and Heaven is about to use your master as its edict announcer."

column2: Comparing the music of the emperor Shun with the music of King Wu, the Master said, "That of Shun is beautiful throughout, and also good throughout.
column3: Comparing the music of the emperor Shun with the music of King Wu, the Master said, "That of Shun is beautiful throughout, and also good throughout.

column2: That of Wu is all of it beautiful, but scarcely all of it good."
column3: That of Wu is all of it beautiful, but scarcely all of it good."

column2: High station, said the Master, "occupied by men who have no large and generous heart; ceremonial performed with no reverence; duties of mourning engaging the attention, where there is absence of sorrow;--how should I look on, where this is the state of things?"
column3: High station, said the Master, "occupied by men who have no large and generous heart; ceremonial performed with no reverence; duties of mourning engaging the attention, where there is absence of sorrow;--how should I look on, where this is the state of things?"

column2: [Footnote 4: The Chief of the Ki clan was virtually the Duke of Lu, under whom Confucius for a time held office.]
column3: [Footnote four: The Chief of the Ki clan was virtually the Duke of Lu, under whom Confucius for a time held office.]

column2: [Footnote 5: These posturers were mutes who took part in the ritual of the ancestral temple, waving plumes, flags, etc.

column2: Each line or rank of these contained eight men.
column3: Each line or rank of these contained eight men.

column2: Only in the sovereign's household should there have been eight lines of them; a ducal family like the Ki should have had but six lines; a great official had four, and one of lower grade two.
column3: Only in the sovereign's household should there have been eight lines of them; a ducal family like the Ki should have had but six lines; a great official had four, and one of lower grade two.

column2: These were the gradations marking the status of families, and Confucius's sense of propriety was offended at the Ki's usurping in this way the appearance of royalty.]
column3: These were the gradations marking the status of families, and Confucius's sense of propriety was offended at the Ki's usurping in this way the appearance of royalty.]

column2: [Footnote 6: Three great families related to each other, in whose hands the government of the State of Lu then was, and of which the Ki was the chief.]
column3: [Footnote six: Three great families related to each other, in whose hands the government of the State of Lu then was, and of which the Ki was the chief.]

column2: [Footnote 7: One of the five sacred mountains, worshipped upon only by the sovereign.]
column3: [Footnote seven: One of the five sacred mountains, worshipped upon only by the sovereign.]

column2: [Footnote 8: Tsou was Confucius's birthplace; his father was governor of the town.]
column3: [Footnote eight: Tsou was Confucius's birthplace; his father was governor of the town.]

column2: [Footnote 9: A renowned statesman who flourished about two hundred years before Confucius's time.
column3: [Footnote nine: A renowned statesman who flourished about two hundred years before Confucius's time.

column2: A philosophical work on law and government, said to have been written by him, is still extant.
column3: A philosophical work on law and government, said to have been written by him, is still extant.

column2: He was regarded as a sage by the people, but he lacked, in Confucius's eyes, the one thing needful--propriety.]
column3: He was regarded as a sage by the people, but he lacked, in Confucius's eyes, the one thing needful-propriety.]
